name: NPR
text:
BREAKING: President Trump has fired Christopher Krebs, a top cybersecurity official who affirmed the security of the election and rebutted rumors and baseless allegations of widespread voter fraud that Trump promoted.
https://t.co/Z5z8ynkmrT

name: NPR
text:
The Senate GOP failed to secure the votes to advance President Trump's controversial Federal Reserve Board nominee Judy Shelton after key members were absent from the chamber.
https://t.co/lh4X4Ep56G

name: NPR
text:
New research shows the use of the deadly synthetic opioid fentanyl is spreading fast in Los Angeles, Phoenix and Seattle.

Chinese companies have found ways to circumvent export bans — and route the drug through cartels in Mexico.
https://t.co/yEqGRdUa89

name: NPR
text:
Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine has ordered a 3-week statewide curfew, starting Thursday, which mandates that residents be in their homes from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. with few exceptions.
https://t.co/REzL3JXy0G

name: NPR
text:
Two foreign allies of President Trump, India's Narendra Modi and Israel's Benjamin Netanyahu, have spoken to President-elect Joe Biden and congratulated him on his White House victory.
https://t.co/9eFtnX8xFR

name: NPR
text:
Partnering with data analysts at C4ADS, NPR tracked down chemical facilities tucked in sprawling warehouse complexes in China’s far-flung industrial areas.

We discovered vendors marketing potent products on a slew of social media and e-commerce platforms.
https://t.co/0KS4WXhdux

name: NPR
text:
The Trump administration says it will pull thousands of troops out of Iraq and Afghanistan by Jan. 15 and aims to have the remaining forces out by Spring 2021 — a drawdown that has military leaders worried.
https://t.co/grMp8YJ3vy

name: NPR
text: Twitter joins the fray of other social apps that have a stories feature. Called "Fleets" users can now share text, images and tweets for a short time. https://t.co/xkyTPWGutO

name: NPR
text:
The veteran Democratic aide John Jones is in the mix to head President-elect Biden's Office of Management and Budget, sources tell NPR. Jones has deep ties with the Congressional Black Caucus.
https://t.co/W8C1tDOEnZ

name: NPR
text:
President-elect Biden's coronavirus advisers are urgently asking the Trump administration to take the formal step to allow them to access the government's pandemic data and federal scientists.
https://t.co/Ab1pjNo6W4

name: NPR
text:
NEW: The FDA has approved the first COVID-19 diagnostic at-home self-test, which is expected to provide results in 30 minutes or less.
https://t.co/KekE9ttJqN

name: NPR
text:
House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, a Trump ally, was reelected by his colleagues to his post as top GOP leader for the next Congress. His top lieutenants were also reelected.
https://t.co/K83lt9c8a7

name: NPR
text:
A judge approved a controversial $8.3 billion settlement between the Justice Dept. and Purdue Pharma over its marketing of Oxycontin and other addictive opioids.

Under the deal, the Sackler family will admit no wrongdoing and face no criminal charges.
https://t.co/7Vc6FcuJ5a

name: NPR
text:
Things did not go well on Tuesday for the Trump campaign's effort to stop certification of the Pennsylvania vote count — which has President-elect Biden ahead by more than 73,000 votes.
https://t.co/i6lGY6p87G

name: NPR
text: Delphine Minoui's slim new book tells the true story of a group of Syrian resistance fighters who founded a 15,000-volume library in the basement of an abandoned building. https://t.co/omEDmlxJTf

name: NPR
text:
The House Judiciary Committee is asking the Supreme Court to postpone arguments in a case testing whether the committee has the right to see grand jury materials related to the Trump impeachment inquiry.
https://t.co/zmnyUIzZ0M

name: NPR
text: Virginia's governor, Democrat Ralph Northam, has set a course toward legalizing recreational marijuana in the state; it would be the first Southern state to do so. @wamu885 https://t.co/tnBMsGmmig

name: NPR
text:
A surge in coronavirus testing is driving supply shortages.

Half of labs are reporting shortages of test kits and two-thirds say their supply of crucial chemicals and other supplies are dwindling.
https://t.co/u0lz7wioyv

name: NPR
text: "We do need to get more people surgical care. But if we do it in a model that has been developed in rich countries, it will break the climate,” says Dr. Aaron Bernstein at Harvard. https://t.co/nOyPjqxVAX

name: NPR
text:
With coronavirus infections soaring around the U.S., lots of people are conflicted about Thanksgiving plans. This year, health officials recommend spending the holiday just with people we share a home with.

Here are some precautions you can take.
https://t.co/QYGyvVSAlE

name: NPR
text:
For their Tiny Desk, composer Owen Pallett tried something different: recording four songs in multiple stages on different instruments — acoustic guitar, violin, viola — then layering the recordings.

They explain the process, charmingly, between songs.
https://t.co/O29yPQ12GX

name: NPR
text: Thousands of workers across Georgia are hand-counting the 5 million ballots cast in the state in the 2020 election. @gpbnews digs into exactly how the recount is being conducted and why. https://t.co/ive9sJ5igV

name: NPR
text: NEW: Pfizer's COVID-19 vaccine was found 95% effective in an updated study analysis. The company says it plans to file for FDA emergency use "within days." https://t.co/py6FNgvj1u

name: NPR
text: Lil Wayne was charged in federal court Tuesday with possession of a firearm and ammunition by a felon. The 38-year-old is facing 10 years in prison if convicted. https://t.co/6NHlQxjMeG

name: NPR
text:
House Democrats are expected to reelect Nancy Pelosi for her fourth term as speaker — as they grapple with the unexpected losses of at least eight seats to Republicans this election.
https://t.co/3iMHNBa4BJ

name: NPR
text:
On Monday, President-elect Joe Biden affirmed his support for erasing some student debt "immediately."

The provision calls for the federal government to pay off up to $10,000 in private, nonfederal student loans for "economically distressed" borrowers.
https://t.co/ttKSbM5pjG

name: NPR
text:
Officials in Michigan's most populous county reversed course and certified its election results Tuesday.

It came hours after Republican members of the Wayne County Board of Canvassers faced withering criticism for blocking the move to certify the votes.
https://t.co/Q2BrtLYTug

name: NPR
text:
President Trump's hostility toward China has changed the relationship between the two countries.

Although President-elect Biden will likely set a more polite tone with Beijing, analysts say, he's unlikely to reverse Trump's tariffs.
 https://t.co/61YqjrnQGJ

name: NPR
text:
New research shows the use of the deadly synthetic opioid fentanyl is spreading fast in Los Angeles, Phoenix and Seattle.

Chinese companies have found ways to circumvent export bans — and route the drug through cartels in Mexico.
https://t.co/qGt0IXB63d

name: NPR
text:
President-elect Joe Biden will be taking office in a country that's even more sharply divided along urban-rural lines than it was in 2016.

Experts say the pandemic may be one of the biggest reasons why the divide widened.
https://t.co/4mBphcUSHf

name: NPR
text:
The CFPB is a powerful watchdog agency aimed at policing predatory or unfair practices. The Trump administration defanged it.

But a Supreme Court ruling this past summer allows President-elect Biden to appoint a new director.
https://t.co/Ke80KtgmC9

name: NPR
text:
Police in Berlin used water cannons Wednesday to disperse protesters who refused to wear masks and follow public health measures.

The tightly packed crowd gathered to object to government restrictions aimed at fighting the spread of the coronavirus.
https://t.co/Pkj34ylhAP

name: NPR
text:
Facebook's content moderators — who are contractors — say the company is putting their lives at risk by pressuring them back into offices because its attempt to rely more on automated systems "failed."

"Without our work, Facebook is unusable," they wrote. https://t.co/JOaKJ0eHJ1

name: NPR
text: David Letterman chats with @Bullseye about taking the leap from local television personality to LA stand-up, the brutal grind of hosting a daily talk show, and his mom's reviews of his early attempts at comedy (hint: not good). https://t.co/vrWl1Jl1XK https://t.co/JR01aH9UYL

name: NPR
text:
Bruce Swedien — the audio engineer best known for recording, mixing, and assisting in producing Michael Jackson's "Thriller" — has died. He was 86. 
https://t.co/O8U1PbMwBx

name: NPR
text:
South Australia is entering a strict, mandatory lockdown lasting 6 days that began at midnight Thursday local time.

Facial coverings are required in public, and only one person per household is permitted to leave on a single day for essential activities.
https://t.co/RMTdeYFR36

name: NPR
text: RT @wfyi: Historic spikes in unemployed workers has been one of the biggest stories to come out of the pandemic. Now Indiana is doubling down on a program that helps workers not just recover their jobs, but maybe even get a better one.  https://t.co/J4bPvI3Iqp via @Hicks_JustinM https://t.co/MCB2DwV89c

name: NPR
text:
RT @WBEZ: Chicago-area Catholic schools have stayed in-person through the pandemic. It’s made Chicago Public Schools think it can do the same.

https://t.co/NOKZ9A8N0u

name: NPR
text:
A federal judge has ordered the Trump administration to stop deporting unaccompanied minors on the grounds that they're a coronavirus threat. 

It has already expelled nearly 9,000 children who crossed the border alone, citing a CDC public health order.
 https://t.co/RSZf9xk4DJ

name: NPR
text:
Critics say President Trump is taking abrupt military moves that lack a clear strategic goal, complicate a transition to a Biden presidency, confuse U.S. allies and harm American standing in the world.

Here's a break down of what he's done in recent days:
https://t.co/2NFy2NRH4i

name: NPR
text: JUST IN: 250,000 Americans have now died from COVID-19. That's more than twice the number of U.S. service members killed in World War I. https://t.co/TceQmpQTtQ
